coreConcepts.title: Finding the Degree of a Monomial
coreConcepts.description: The degree of a monomial is the sum of the exponents of all its variables. A nonzero constant has degree 0.

coreConcepts.title: Polynomials
coreConcepts.description: A polynomial is a monomial or a sum of monomials. Each monomial is called a term of the polynomial. A polynomial with two terms is a binomial. A polynomial with three terms is a trinomial.
coreConcepts.notes: The degree of a polynomial is the greatest degree of its terms. A polynomial in one variable is in standard form when the exponents decrease from left to right. The leading coefficient is the coefficient of the first term.

coreConcepts.title: Adding Polynomials
coreConcepts.description: To add polynomials, add like terms. You can use a vertical or horizontal format.

items.detail: Distribute the negative sign to each term of the polynomial being subtracted.

coreConcepts.title: Solving a Real-Life Problem
coreConcepts.description: Polynomials can model real-world situations such as profit, area, and trajectory calculations.

extras.label: Tip
extras.content: When solving real-life problems, define variables clearly and write polynomial expressions that represent the situation. Then simplify by combining like terms.

coreConcepts.title: Multiplying Monomials
coreConcepts.description: To multiply monomials, multiply the coefficients and add the exponents of like bases.

coreConcepts.title: FOIL Method
coreConcepts.description: The FOIL Method is a shortcut for multiplying two binomials. Find the sum of the products of the First terms, Outer terms, Inner terms, and Last terms.
coreConcepts.notes: First: $x(x) = x^2$, Outer: $x(2) = 2x$, Inner: $1(x) = x$, Last: $1(2) = 2$

coreConcepts.title: Multiplying a Binomial and a Trinomial
coreConcepts.description: Use the Distributive Property to multiply each term of the binomial by each term of the trinomial, then combine like terms.

coreConcepts.title: Solving a Real-Life Problem

monitoringProgress.instruction: Use the FOIL Method to find the product.

problems.text: In the example above, how does the area change if the length is three times the width? Express the area in terms of $w$.

problems.info: Binomial times trinomial (not just FOIL)
problems.hint: FOIL only works for two binomials. Here, distribute each term of the binomial across all three terms of the trinomial.

problems.info: Monomial times trinomial with negative coefficient
problems.hint: Distribute the monomial (including its negative sign) to each term. Watch the sign rules for multiplication.

problems.info: Product of three binomials
problems.hint: Multiply the first two binomials, then multiply that result by the third. Take it step by step.

problems.info: FOIL with larger coefficients
problems.hint: Apply FOIL normally: First, Outer, Inner, Last. The coefficients are larger but the process is the same.

problems.info: Fraction coefficient in binomial product
problems.hint: Treat fractions like any coefficient. Multiply normally and simplify the resulting fractions.

problems.info: Binomials with squared variable terms
problems.hint: The variable is $m^2$ instead of $m$. Apply FOIL treating $m^2$ as your variable.

problems.hint: Write $(x+4)^3 = (x+4)(x+4)(x+4)$. Multiply the first two, then multiply that result by $(x+4)$.

extras.content: The diagram shows a square with side length $(a + b)$. The area is divided into four regions: $a^2$, $ab$, $ab$, and $b^2$. Total area = $a^2 + 2ab + b^2$.

problems.info: Square of a binomial with larger coefficients
problems.hint: Use $(a - b)^2 = a^2 - 2ab + b^2$. Here $a = 3x$ and $b = 7$. Square each and double the product.

problems.info: Square of binomial with two variables
problems.hint: Apply the same pattern: $(a + b)^2 = a^2 + 2ab + b^2$ where $a = 2a$ and $b = 5b$.

problems.info: Sum and difference with two variables
problems.hint: Use $(a - b)(a + b) = a^2 - b^2$. Identify $a$ and $b$ with their coefficients.

problems.info: Square of a binomial with $x^2$ term
problems.hint: The pattern still applies with higher powers: $(x^2)^2 = x^4$. Use $(a + b)^2$ with $a = x^2$.

problems.info: Reversed order: constant first in binomial
problems.hint: $(5 - 2t)^2$ still follows the square pattern. Be careful: $(5)^2 = 25$ and $(-2t)^2 = 4t^2$.

problems.info: Sum and difference with $n^2$ terms
problems.hint: Recognize this as $(a - b)(a + b) = a^2 - b^2$ where $a = n^2$ and $b = 4$, giving $n^4 - 16$.

cornerCases.instruction: Use special products to evaluate the expression mentally.

problems.info: Mental math using sum-and-difference pattern
problems.hint: Rewrite as $(30-1)(30+1)$. This is a difference of squares: $30^2 - 1^2$.

problems.info: Mental math using square of binomial
problems.hint: Rewrite as $(50+2)^2$. Apply $(a+b)^2 = a^2 + 2ab + b^2$ with $a=50$, $b=2$.

coreConcepts.description: If the product of two real numbers is 0, then at least one of the numbers is 0.

items.detail: Width $= w$, Length $= w + 4$, Area $= w(w + 4) = 60$

coreConcepts.title: Factoring $x^2 + bx + c$ When $c$ Is Positive
coreConcepts.description: $x^2 + bx + c = (x + p)(x + q)$ when $p + q = b$ and $pq = c$. When $c$ is positive, $p$ and $q$ have the same sign as $b$.

coreConcepts.title: Factoring $x^2 + bx + c$ When $c$ Is Negative
coreConcepts.description: $x^2 + bx + c = (x + p)(x + q)$ when $p + q = b$ and $pq = c$. When $c$ is negative, $p$ and $q$ have different signs.

problems.hint: When $c < 0$ and $b < 0$, the number with larger absolute value is negative.

problems.hint: The variable name doesn't matter — the factoring process is identical. Factor $t^2 - 14t + 45$ just like $x^2 - 14x + 45$.

problems.hint: Find two numbers that multiply to $-72$ and add to $1$. Since the product is negative, one number is positive and one negative.

problems.info: Equation with variable on both sides
problems.hint: Rearrange to $m^2 - 7m + 10 = 0$ first, then factor. Find two numbers multiplying to 10 and adding to $-7$.

coreConcepts.title: Factoring When $a \neq 1$
coreConcepts.description: When factoring $ax^2 + bx + c$ where $a \neq 1$, consider the factor pairs of both $a$ and $c$ to find the correct combination, or use the ac-method.

items.detail: $a \cdot c = 2 \cdot 3 = 6$. Find factors of $6$ that add to $7$: $1$ and $6$.
$a \cdot c = 3 \cdot 4 = 12$. Find factors of $12$ that add to $-8$: $-2$ and $-6$.

coreConcepts.title: Factoring Out the GCF First
coreConcepts.description: Always check for a greatest common factor before attempting to factor a trinomial.

extras.label: Study Tip
extras.content: When factoring $ax^2 + bx + c$, always check first whether the terms have a common factor. If they do, factor it out first.

problems.hint: Recognize $49x^2 = (7x)^2$ and $64 = 8^2$. Apply $a^2 - b^2 = (a+b)(a-b)$.

problems.hint: $x^4 = (x^2)^2$ and $81 = 9^2$. Factor as $(x^2 + 9)(x^2 - 9)$. Note: $x^2 - 9$ can be factored further!

problems.hint: Check if $(5t)^2 = 25t^2$, $(3)^2 = 9$, and $2(5t)(3) = 30t$. If the middle term matches, it's a perfect square.

Two-variable difference of squares
problems.hint: $(3x)^2 - (2y)^2 = (3x + 2y)(3x - 2y)$. The pattern works the same with two different variables.

problems.hint: Factor as $(x + 6)^2 = 0$. A perfect square gives only ONE solution (a double root).

coreConcepts.title: Factoring by Grouping
coreConcepts.description: To factor a polynomial with four terms, group the terms into pairs. Factor the GCF out of each pair of terms. Look for and factor out the common binomial factor. This process is called factoring by grouping.

coreConcepts.description: Practice factoring four-term polynomials by grouping.

coreConcepts.title: Factoring Completely
coreConcepts.description: Use multiple factoring strategies together. Always start by factoring out the GCF.

problems.info: Recognizing incomplete factoring — original expression is not fully factored
problems.hint: Check if any factor can be factored further. $x^2 - 4$ is a difference of squares! But $x^2 + 1$ cannot be factored over integers.

problems.info: Identifying when factoring IS complete
problems.hint: $x^2 + 1$ has no real factors (sum of squares doesn't factor). This one is already completely factored.

problems.info: Verifying complete factoring with monomial GCF
problems.hint: $5x^2(x-7)$ — check each factor: $5$ is prime, $x^2$ can't factor further, $(x-7)$ is linear. It's complete.
